awd_titl_txt: Regulation of the AAA+ protein Sec18 through membrane lipid modification
awd_abstract_narration:
Eukaryotic cells are compartmentalized into organelles that communicate through the trafficking of membranous transport vesicles. Cargo transfer is finalized through the fusion of these compartments. Many proteins control fusion, yet the role of the membrane itself remains under-examined. Membranes contain specialized lipids that are essential for fusion and the PI's lab examines how these lipids affect protein function during fusion. Altering lipid content negatively affects fusion, however the mechanisms are unknown. The long-term goal of this project is to elucidate how lipid modification affects membrane fusion. The project will allow the investigator to continue his training of scientists at all levels, including female and other underrepresented students. This research will benefit society by spreading scientific discovery and education broadly to students from all walks of life. 

Eukaryotic cellular homeostasis is maintained in part through membrane fusion, which is catalyzed by SNARE proteins. Prior to fusion, inactive SNARE complexes are disassembled into individual proteins by Sec18/NSF. The PI's lab discovered that phosphatidic acid (PA) binds Sec18 to sequester it from SNAREs. The PA phosphatase Pah1/Lipin1 converts PA to diacylglycerol to release Sec18 and allows it to engage SNAREs. The objective of this research is to undertake a detailed analysis of the interactions between PA and Sec18. First, they will use biochemical, biophysical and computational approaches to define the PA binding sites on Sec18. Second, they will elucidate how PA-binding induces Sec18 conformational changes. Third, they will test conservation of Sec18 regulation by PA in other organelles. The completion of this project will define the how Sec18 is regulated by the membrane to activate SNAREs.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Project Outcomes Report

NSF Award: 1818310

Principal Investigator: Rutilio A. Fratti

 

Eukaryotic cells are compartmentalized into membrane bound organelles that communicate with each other by sending and receiving packages in the form of vesicles containing specific cargo. The delivery of cargo depends on the merger of membranes into a continuous compartment that occurs via a multi-stage cycle collectively termed the fusion pathway. This cycle uses stage-specific proteins to execute functions needed to progress to the next phase. The final stage is carried out by proteins called SNAREs that pull membranes together and exert the required force needed to merge the membranes. While proteins have received most of the attention, the effects of the membrane itself often goes ignored. Membranes contain bulk lipids that make up the structure and a small collection of specialized lipids that are active in the regulation of protein function, including SNAREs.

 

Our research focused on the regulation of the fusion pathway by the regulatory lipids imbedded in vacuolar lysosomes from the model organism Saccharomyces cerevisiae, commonly known as baker’s yeast.  Vacuoles isolated from cells contain all the proteins and lipids needed to fuse and can be used in test-tube assays to examine the role of different lipids on the fusion cycle.

 

As part of a cyclic pathway, proteins need to be recycled and reactivated. After fusion, spent SNAREs are reactivated through mechanical separation using ATP hydrolysis as a source of energy. This allows the newly activated SNAREs to interact with SNAREs on a new fusion partner membrane. The machine used to activate SNAREs is called Sec18 which forms a hexamer when functional. We discovered that monomeric copies of Sec18 are sequestered away from SNAREs through interactions with the lipid phosphatidic acid (PA). For Sec18 to be released and form an active hexamer the PA must be cleaved by the phosphatase Pah1. This removes a key negatively charged phosphate from PA, which leads to the release of Sec18 from the membrane. Our work showed that PA binding induced a large shape change in Sec18 monomers that block it from forming the active hexamer. In a follow up study, we discovered a small molecule that bound to the same site on Sec18 that PA occupies. This allowed us to further study Sec18 regulation with a drug instead of the natively produced lipid.

Aside from PA, there are several regulatory lipids that contain an inositol sugar head group called phosphoinositides (PI) that can be differentially modified by the addition and subtraction of phosphates at three of the six carbons. One PI that had not been studied in the fusion cycle was PI(3,5)P2, which has phosphates on the 3rd and 5th carbons of inositol. Our studies found that PI(3,5)P2 was required for fusion and that it functions after SNAREs form complexes between membranes, but before they can trigger fusion. The requirement for PI(3,5)P2 was biphasic in that small amounts were essential but too much of the lipid inhibited the fusion pathway. A subsequent study found that PI(3,5)P2 inhibited the fusion pathway in part through dysregulating calcium (Ca2+) transport across the vacuole membrane. We found that the excess of PI(3,5)P2 hyperactivated Ca2+ uptake by the pump Pmc1, whereas its absence blocked uptake. Ca2+ can have many effects on vacuole homeostasis including its acidification by the V-ATPase which pumps H+ into the vacuole lumen. We found that PI(3,5)P2 levels can alter how Pmc1 forms a complex with the SNARE Nvy1 and Vph1, a subunit of the V-ATPase. This led us to ask how PI(3,5)P2 affected vacuole acidification.

 

Others has shown that PI(3,5)P2 can directly bind Vph1 and lead to its stabilization to increase its function. We expanded on this and further asked how Ca2+ transport could affect V-ATPase function. We found that mutants that overproduced PI(3,5)P2 enhanced V-ATPase activity whereas mutants that cannot produce PI(3,5)P2 showed reduced acidification. We next showed that the amount of extraluminal Ca2+ modulates V-ATPase activity. Excess Ca2+ blocked V-ATPase activity and overall vacuole acidification. Finally we found that although PI(3,5)P2 affected Ca2+ and V-ATPase activity, the two effects were not linked. This was shown by the ability of Ca2+ to inhibit V-ATPase activity in the presence or absence of PI(3,5)P2. We found that the reason for this was the activation of the Ca2+/H+ exchanger Vcx1.

 

Finally, this funding led us to discover that a different type of regulatory lipids called sphingolipids affect vacuole homeostasis through altering membrane fluidity. The absence of sphingolipids causes the membrane to become too fluid (floppy) and inhibits the phase between SNARE activation and membrane fusion. This manifests as inhibited membrane contact that is regulated by the Rab GTPase Ypt7/Rab7.
